, who is now gone to sea, and another man, slept in a doublebedded-room, on the 9th of January, in my house; the prosecutor came down and said he had lost his cap - I told him it was not possible, as no one had left the house, and I told him to go and look under the clothes; he did so, but could not find it - on the Saturday following I went to the Anchor and Hope public-house, and found the prisoner there intoxicated, and to my great surprise he had this cap on his head, which I knew to be the prosecutor's, as I had had it in my possession before, and I knew it by this mark.
Prisoner. Q. Did not 1 lose a pair of trousers that night? A. You said you did, and your waistcoat; I went and got you a pair.
JAMES FOGG. I took the prisoner, and produce the cap.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the cap of a man that came from St. Mary-axe, and the publican took it off my head, because he thought I would not pay him a little money.
GUILTY . Aged 11.
Confined Six Weeks .

521.
JOHN SMITH
and
JAMES HILBERT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January , 4 carriage glasses, value 4l. , the goods of
Watkin William Martin
.

WILLIAM SUMMERFIELD. I am a watchman of Mary-le-bone. On the 11th of January, at a quarter before seven o'clock in the morning, I was in Adam-street, Westminster
- I watched the premises of Mr. Martin, a stable-keeper , in consequence of information, and saw the two prisoners cross Upper Berkley-street, which is two or three hundred yards from Mr. Martin's - they were in company, and coming towards me; I am positive they are the two men: Smith was carrying something - I went and clapped my hand upon his shoulder, and said,

"You are the very fellow I want;" I took these eight glasses from under his arm - Hilbert immediately decamped; I called for assistance and gave Smith into custody - Hilbert ran into Upper Seymour-street; I ran and took him as he was stooping as if going to tie his shoe - I am confident he was with Smith.

WILLIAM GOROON
. I am a gas-lighter. On Sunday morning, the 11th of January, at a quarter before seven o'clock, I saw the two prisoners in the news and gave information to the watchman - Smith asked me what o'clock it was.

WATKINS WILLIAM MARTIN. I am a liverystablekeeper - my stable is in the mews; these four glasses are my property - they were in post-chaises which were standing in the mews; I have no doubt they are mine - one is broken and the piece of it is left behind; they would cost me about 8l.

SMITH'S Defence. I was passing by the mews, and saw two young men pass with these glasses under their arms- they went to a watch-box, returned and placed them against the side of the mews, and when the watchman came by, they went to a watch-box, returned and placed them against the side of the mews, and when the watchman came by, they decamped; I staid till be passed, and then I must own I was going to take away the glasses.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 23.

HILBERT -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

522.
JOHN SMITH
and
JAMES HILBERT
were again indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January , 4 carriage glasses, value 4l. , the goods of
Edward Kirkley
.

WILLIAM SUMMERFIELD
. I am a watchman. Mr. Kirkley is a livery stable-keeper , in Cumberland-mews North
, near to Williams'- mews; I received information a quarter before seven o'clock on the morning of the 11th of January, and saw the prisoners two or three hundred yards from the mews; I took the glasses from Smith, and said,"You are the very lad I am looking for;" I gave him into custody, then pursued Hilbert, who had run away, and took him.

WILLIAM GORDON
. I saw the prisoner in Williams'-mews, Adam-street, not far from Mr. Kirkley's premises. I gave information to the watchman.

EDWARD KIRKLEY. I am a livery stable-keeper -These four glasses are mine; I can be quite positive of two of them, by some lace on the frame, which matches the lace on the chaise - I had lent my chaise to Mr. Martin the day before, and they were on his premises, next to his chaises: they are worth 8l.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 23.

HILBERT -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

523.
CATHERINE WILLIAMS
and
ELIZABETH SULLIVAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of January , 2 coats, value 3l.; 1 pair of boots, value 12s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 6s.; 1 waistcoat, value 5s.; 1 bat, vlaue 7s., and 3 handkerchiefs, value 10s. , the goods of
George Eastham
.

GEORGE EASTHAM
. I am a tailor , and live in Church-place, Somer's-town. On the 12th of January I lost the articles stated in St. Giles'
; the two prisoners caught me in the street, and carried me to their apartments; I was drunk- the clothes were on my back: I awoke about four o'clock, in the prisoners' apartments - some of my clothes were stopped upon them.

THOMAS HOBBS. I am a watchman of Whitechapel. At half-past two o'clock on the morning of the 13th of January, I met the two prisoners; I followed them to Rosemary-lane, where I called another watchman - we went and took them: I asked what they had got - they said, clothes belonging to their husbands, and they had taken them out of pawn; I said I did not believe it, being that time in the morning: the things were under their shawls - I took a hat and a close body coat from Williams.
THOMAS FOLKER. Hobbs called me to his assistance, and I secured Sullivan - she said she had got her husband's coat, and I found this light drab coat on her.
THOMAS BROWN. I took charge of the prisoners. I found this handkerchief in Sullivan's pocket, and this other was in the great coat pocket.

GEORGE EASTHAM. These are my property. I had been spending the day in town, and had no memory; I met the prisoners in Oxford-street - I me Sullivan first, who asked me to treat her; I refused at first, but I did treat her - another woman was with her, but I cannot tell whether it was the other prisoner.
SULLIVAN'S Defence. We were coming home, and met with this parcel at a door - we took it, and the watchmen detained us; we were making the best of our way home.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

SULLIVAN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

524.
JAMES LOVE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , I mustard-pot, value 4l.; 3 salt-cellars, value 2l.; I decanter, value 10s., and 1 basket, value 6d. , the goods of
William Carter
, his master.

WILLIAM CARTER. I am a China and glass-seller . -The prisoner was my errand-boy ; he had been with me a week or ten days - I delivered him these artices on the 4th of July, to take to Messrs. Pellatt and Green's glass-house, to have glass linings to them, and a decanter to the stand; they were silver - he never returned: I never found him till lately, when he was taken on another charge.
WILLIAM MYNER. I am warehouse clerk to Messrs. Pellatt and Green. This property was not brought to my employors'; if they had I should have known it.
WILLIAM JUDGE. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner for robbing his master, the Captain of a vessel.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

525.
THOMAS CALVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of January , 1 umbrella, value 7s. , the goods of
Alexander Smyth
, from his person.

ALEXANDER SMYTH. I live in Mark-lane. On the 14th of January I was coming from Covent-garden Theatre; I walked as far as Norfolk-street
- Mrs. Smyth had hold of my arm, and I had my umbrella in my right hand; I felt a severe pull at it, but I did not let it go: presently I felt a more severe pull, which bent my wrist, opened my hand, and got away my umbrella; I pursued the prisoner - a gentleman followed, and took him: I came up, and he was delivered up to me - I gave him in charge; I am certain he is the man.

WILLIAM JOHN McBEATH
. I was on my way from Waterloo-bridge to Norfolk - street; I saw this gentleman and his lady followed by the prisoner - I saw the Strand; which got the umbrella from him; the gentleman called out that he had robbed him of his umbrella: I followed the prisoner, and took him by the New church in the Strand; I am positive he is the man.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
